overview.brief_description: Scotland's capital blends medieval Old Town lanes, elegant Georgian squares, and volcanic landscapes into one of Europe's most atmospheric cities.

sections.title: Historic Layers
sections.content: Centuries of history sit side by side on the Royal Mile, where closes, wynds, and hidden courtyards connect Edinburgh Castle with Holyrood Palace.

sections.title: Festival Capital
sections.content: From the world-famous Fringe and International Festival to Hogmanay fireworks, Edinburgh's calendar overflows with cultural celebrations.

sections.title: Storybook Landscapes
sections.content: Arthur's Seat, Calton Hill, and the Water of Leith offer dramatic vistas and outdoor adventures within minutes of bustling streets.

sections.title: Creative Dining
sections.content: Modern Scottish chefs champion seasonal produce, whisky pairings, and fresh North Sea seafood alongside traditional favorites like haggis and Cullen skink.

why_visit.intro: Edinburgh charms travelers with layers of history, a thriving arts scene, and rugged natural backdrops that inspire exploration year-round.

highlights.title: Edinburgh Castle
highlights.content: Perched on Castle Rock, the fortress houses the Honours of Scotland and sweeping views across the city.

highlights.title: Royal Mile
highlights.content: Medieval closes, folk tales, whisky bars, and artisan shops connect the castle with Holyrood Palace.

highlights.title: Festival Season
highlights.content: August brings the Fringe, International Festival, and Military Tattoo, turning the city into a global stage.

highlights.title: Natural Escapes
highlights.content: Climb Arthur's Seat at sunrise, stroll Dean Village along the Water of Leith, or watch sunsets from Calton Hill.

highlights.title: Scottish Flavors
highlights.content: Sample whisky flights, hearty seafood chowders, and contemporary tasting menus celebrating Scottish larder.

highlights.title: Museums & Galleries
highlights.content: Discover Scottish history at the National Museum, masterpieces at the National Galleries, and writers at the Writers' Museum.

transport.public_transport: Lothian Buses and Edinburgh Trams offer comprehensive coverage with contactless payments and capped daily fares.
transport.passes: Consider a Ridacard or day ticket for unlimited tram and bus travel; trains connect easily to Glasgow and the Highlands.

spring.description: Cherry blossom lines The Meadows, festivals return, and mild weather invites Old Town walks and day trips to the Borders.

summer.description: Festival season fills streets with performers, fireworks, and late sunsets while nearby beaches offer breezy escapes.

autumn.description: Golden foliage blankets Princes Street Gardens and Arthur's Seat while whisky bars glow with warm light.

winter.description: Hogmanay celebrations, twinkling lights on George Street, and cozy pubs make the dark season atmospheric and festive.

january.title: Warm up with a whisky tasting
january.description: Join a guided flight at the Scotch Whisky Experience and learn the story of the Highlands and Islands.

february.title: Explore the National Museum of Scotland
february.description: Hands-on galleries and the roof terrace offer a winter-friendly day out.

march.title: Walk the Water of Leith
march.description: Spot herons and historic mills along the 12km riverside path between Balerno and Leith.

april.title: Picnic beneath The Meadows blossom
april.description: Locals celebrate spring by gathering under the park's cherry trees.

may.title: Climb Arthur's Seat at sunrise
may.description: Enjoy panoramic views as the city lights fade and daylight stretches.

june.title: Tour the Royal Botanic Garden
june.description: Guided walks highlight Victorian glasshouses and Scottish plant collections.

july.title: Attend the International Jazz & Blues Festival
july.description: Music spills into venues across Old Town ahead of Fringe season.

august.title: Experience the Edinburgh Festival Fringe
august.description: Catch comedy, theatre, and experimental performances around every corner.

september.title: Take a day trip to the Borders
september.description: Visit Rosslyn Chapel and Melrose Abbey amid autumn colors.

october.title: Join a ghost tour of the Old Town
october.description: Explore haunted closes and hidden vaults with costumed storytellers.

november.title: Watch fireworks on Calton Hill
november.description: Bonfire Night illuminations pair with stunning skyline views.

december.title: Browse Edinburgh's Christmas Market
december.description: Festive stalls, mulled wine, and a Ferris wheel take over Princes Street Gardens.

sites.name: Edinburgh Castle
sites.description: Dominating the skyline from Castle Rock, this ancient stronghold houses Scotland's Crown Jewels, the Stone of Destiny, and dramatic exhibits on the nation's military history.
sites.seasonal_notes: Extremely popular during summer festivals. The 1 o'clock gun is fired daily except Sunday.
sites.booking_tips: Pre-book timed tickets online to skip the entry queue, especially in July and August.

sites.name: Royal Mile
sites.description: Edinburgh's most famous thoroughfare runs from the Castle to Holyrood Palace, lined with medieval closes, souvenir shops, hidden courtyards, and lively street performers.
sites.seasonal_notes: Buzzes with activity during Edinburgh Festival Fringe in August; can be windy in winter.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Guided walking tours add context to the closes and historical anecdotes.

sites.name: Palace of Holyroodhouse
sites.description: The King's official residence in Scotland, famed for the opulent State Apartments, Mary Queen of Scots' chambers, and serene Holyrood Abbey ruins.
sites.seasonal_notes: Closed during royal visits, typically late spring. Gardens are at their best in May and June.
sites.booking_tips: Check the official calendar for closures. Audio guides included with online ticket purchases.

sites.name: Arthur's Seat
sites.description: An ancient volcano rising above the city with sweeping 360-degree views over Edinburgh and the Firth of Forth, popular for sunrise hikes.
sites.seasonal_notes: Trails can be muddy in winter; strong winds common. Wildflowers peak late spring.
sites.booking_tips: No booking needed. Wear sturdy footwear and bring layers; weather changes quickly.

sites.name: National Museum of Scotland
sites.description: Modern galleries span Scottish history, natural sciences, world cultures, and technology. The rooftop terrace offers excellent Old Town views.
sites.seasonal_notes: Families flock during school holidays. Temporary exhibitions may require paid tickets.
sites.booking_tips: Free entry but reserve timed slots for special exhibits in advance.

sites.name: St Giles' Cathedral
sites.description: The High Kirk of Edinburgh features stunning stained glass, a 15th-century crown spire, and memorials to key figures in Scottish history.
sites.seasonal_notes: Donations encouraged. Choir performances and services can limit visitor access.
sites.booking_tips: Join a brief guided tour for deeper historical context; small photography fee applies.

sites.name: Scottish National Gallery
sites.description: Houses masterpieces by Titian, Rembrandt, and the Scottish Colourists within a neoclassical building on The Mound.
sites.seasonal_notes: Renovation work may close sections; check ahead. Quietest on weekday afternoons.
sites.booking_tips: Free admission. Reserve tickets for special exhibits that occasionally require payment.

sites.name: Camera Obscura & World of Illusions
sites.description: A playful six-floor museum of optical illusions featuring kaleidoscopes, holograms, and a historic rooftop camera obscura show.
sites.seasonal_notes: Very busy on rainy days and during school holidays; timed entry system in place.
sites.booking_tips: Purchase tickets online to lock in a timeslot and avoid queues.

sites.name: Calton Hill
sites.description: A short climb rewards visitors with iconic skyline views framed by the National Monument, Nelson Monument, and Dugald Stewart Monument.
sites.seasonal_notes: Windy year-round. Sunrise and sunset photography is particularly popular.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Bring a tripod if planning twilight photography.

sites.name: Royal Yacht Britannia
sites.description: The former royal yacht now docked in Leith offers a glimpse into royal life at sea, from state apartments to crew quarters and the onboard Rolls-Royce.
sites.seasonal_notes: Less crowded outside of peak summer. Accessible year-round thanks to covered walkways.
sites.booking_tips: Buy tickets online. Audio guides included and available in multiple languages.

sites.name: Dean Village
sites.description: A tranquil pocket of cobbled lanes and mill buildings along the Water of Leith, offering a peaceful escape from the busy city center.
sites.seasonal_notes: Most picturesque in spring and autumn when foliage is vibrant.
sites.booking_tips: No booking needed. Combine with a walk along the Water of Leith walkway.

sites.name: Princes Street Gardens
sites.description: A landscaped park in the shadow of Edinburgh Castle featuring seasonal floral displays, the Scott Monument, and festive markets in winter.
sites.seasonal_notes: Hosts Edinburgh's Christmas markets and Hogmanay events. Spring blooms and autumn colors are highlights.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Arrive early during Christmas market season to avoid crowds.

neighborhoods.name: Old Town
neighborhoods.character: Medieval streets stacked along volcanic ridges with closes, wynds, and atmospheric courtyards.

location.description: UNESCO-listed historic core climbing from Holyrood Palace to Edinburgh Castle.

history.overview: Old Town grew within fortified walls from the 12th century, forming a vertical city of tenements and hidden closes.
history.significance: Heart of Scottish royal power, Reformation politics, and Enlightenment thinkers.
notable_events: Signing of the Treaty of Union debates (1706)
Founding of the University of Edinburgh's Old College

practical_info.safety: Busy and generally safe; cobblestones can be slippery in rain.
practical_info.best_time_to_visit: Early morning before tour groups or evenings during festival season.
practical_info.walkability: High but steep; expect many stairs and uneven paving.

attractions.name: Edinburgh Castle
attractions.description: Iconic castle with Crown Jewels, Stone of Destiny, and panoramic views.
attractions.appeal: Essential Scottish history with daily One o'Clock Gun.

attractions.name: Real Mary King's Close
attractions.description: Subterranean streets revealing life in 17th-century Edinburgh.

attractions.name: Scottish Parliament
attractions.description: Contemporary building with free tours explaining devolved government.
attractions.appeal: Architectural contrast at the foot of the Royal Mile.

activities.name: Ghost Walk
activities.description: Storytellers guide guests through haunted closes and vaults.

activities.name: Arthur's Seat Sunrise
activities.description: Ascend the extinct volcano for first light over the city.

stay_here_if: You want to step outside into history
You are attending festival shows all day
insider_tips: Use the closes connecting the Royal Mile to Cowgate for shortcuts.
Visit early on Sundays for unobstructed photos.

neighborhoods.name: New Town
neighborhoods.character: Elegant Georgian crescents, designer boutiques, and refined cocktail bars.

location.description: Planned 18th-century district north of Princes Street with grid layout and grand squares.

history.overview: Built during the Enlightenment to expand the city for wealthy residents fleeing crowded Old Town.
history.significance: Showcase of Georgian architecture and birthplace of the Scottish Enlightenment salons.

practical_info.safety: Very safe with late-night foot traffic and CCTV.
practical_info.best_time_to_visit: Evening for cocktails and illuminated monuments.
practical_info.walkability: Flat grid system with wide pavements.

attractions.name: Scott Monument
attractions.description: Climb 287 steps for city and castle views.

attractions.name: Scottish National Portrait Gallery
attractions.description: Portraits of influential Scots in a red sandstone neo-Gothic building.
attractions.appeal: Free entry and stunning Great Hall.

dining.name: Badger & Co.
dining.known_for: Wind in the Willows themed decor

activities.name: Princes Street Gardens Stroll
activities.description: Admire seasonal plantings under castle cliffs.

activities.name: George Street Cocktail Crawl
activities.description: Explore award-winning bars like Bramble and Panda & Sons.

stay_here_if: You enjoy luxury hotels and shopping
You want easy tram access to the airport
insider_tips: Many museums are free-plan rainy day visits.
Book rooftop bars for sunset views toward the castle.

neighborhoods.name: Stockbridge
neighborhoods.character: Leafy village vibe with Sunday markets, artisan shops, and riverside walks.

location.description: Northwest of New Town along the Water of Leith.

history.overview: Former mill town turned artists' enclave celebrating slow living and independent businesses.
history.significance: Victorian terraces and mews houses illustrate Edinburgh's 19th-century expansion.
notable_events: Opening of the Royal Botanic Garden at Inverleith

transit: Cycle paths along Water of Leith
practical_info.best_time_to_visit: Sunday for the farmers' market and brunch.
practical_info.walkability: Flat, compact streets perfect for strolling.

attractions.name: Dean Village
attractions.description: Picturesque former milling village with cobbled lanes.

attractions.name: Royal Botanic Garden Edinburgh
attractions.description: Expansive garden with Victorian glasshouses and Scottish plant collections.

activities.name: Water of Leith Walkway
activities.description: Scenic path linking Stockbridge with Leith and galleries.

activities.name: Stockbridge Market
activities.description: Sunday market selling artisan food, crafts, and produce.

stay_here_if: You want a neighborhood base with easy access to the center
You love independent cafes and boutiques
avoid_if: You prefer hotel amenities over apartments
insider_tips: Visit early to snap Dean Village before crowds.
Walk to Circus Lane for iconic Instagram shots.

neighborhoods.name: Leith
neighborhoods.character: Revitalised port with creative energy, Michelin dining, and waterfront bars.

location.description: Coastal district northeast of city centre around the Water of Leith docks.

history.overview: Once Scotland's busiest port, now a cultural hotspot blending maritime heritage with creative industries.
history.significance: Stage for historic trade with continental Europe and 21st-century regeneration success story.
notable_events: Arrival of the Royal Yacht Britannia (1998)

practical_info.safety: Generally safe; lively weekend nightlife on The Shore.
practical_info.best_time_to_visit: Evening for waterfront dining and sunsets.
practical_info.walkability: Flat promenades with long boardwalk stretches.

attractions.name: Royal Yacht Britannia
attractions.description: Tour the former floating palace of the Royal Family.
attractions.appeal: Insight into royal life with audio-guided decks.

attractions.name: Custom House
attractions.description: Georgian building hosting pop-up markets and art events.

dining.name: The Shore
dining.known_for: Classic fish dishes and live jazz

activities.name: Leith Theatre gig
activities.description: Historic theatre revived for festivals and concerts.

activities.name: Water of Leith cycle
activities.description: Cycle path to city centre and Pentlands.

stay_here_if: You want top-tier dining within walking distance
avoid_if: You need immediate access to Old Town sights
insider_tips: Take the tram from the airport straight to the Shore.
Sample small-batch spirits at Lind and Lime distillery.

neighborhoods.name: Southside & Meadows
neighborhoods.character: Student energy, green expanses, and cultural venues near the University of Edinburgh.

location.description: South of Old Town surrounding George Square and The Meadows park.

history.overview: Grew in the 18th century as planned terraces for academics and professionals.
history.significance: Academic heart of the city hosting festivals, lecture series, and innovative arts venues.
notable_events: Site of the International Science Festival

practical_info.safety: Safe but lively late at night with students.
practical_info.best_time_to_visit: Spring when cherry blossom lines the park.
practical_info.walkability: Excellent; flat pathways connect to Old Town.

attractions.name: Surgeons' Hall Museums
attractions.description: Medical curiosities and surgical history exhibits.

attractions.name: Summerhall
attractions.description: Arts hub with galleries, theatres, and Pickering's Gin distillery.

activities.name: Meadows Picnic
activities.description: Join locals for frisbee, picnics, and festivals on sunny days.

activities.name: Fringe Venues
activities.description: George Square Gardens hosts major Fringe stages each August.

stay_here_if: You enjoy green space and easy access to Old Town
You want festival venues on your doorstep
insider_tips: Rent a bike to explore the Innocent Railway path to Portobello.
Visit the Meadows farmers market on Saturdays May-September.

neighborhoods.name: Portobello
neighborhoods.character: Seaside suburb with Victorian promenade, independent shops, and cold-water swimming culture.

location.description: Three miles east of the city centre on the Firth of Forth coastline.

history.overview: 18th-century holiday resort that grew with seaside villas and grand baths.
history.significance: Edinburgh's beach escape with thriving independent community.

practical_info.safety: Relaxed and family-friendly; monitor tides when swimming.
practical_info.best_time_to_visit: Summer mornings for sea swims or winter for dramatic skies.
practical_info.walkability: Flat promenade ideal for cycling and prams.

attractions.name: Portobello Beach
attractions.description: Two-mile sandy stretch with views across the Firth of Forth.

attractions.name: Bellfield
attractions.description: Community-owned space hosting yoga, gigs, and markets.
attractions.appeal: Meet locals and support grassroots events.

activities.name: Sea Swim with Wild Ones
activities.description: Join local swimming club for sunrise dips.

activities.name: Promenade Cycle
activities.description: Hire a bike and ride the coastal path toward Musselburgh.

stay_here_if: You want a beach break near the city
You plan a longer stay with self-catering
insider_tips: Bring a towel year-round-locals swim in all seasons.
Visit Twelve Triangles for award-winning pastries after a beach walk.

fine_dining.name: Restaurant Martin Wishart
fine_dining.atmosphere: Intimate waterfront dining with crisp linens
fine_dining.booking_tips: Reserve 4-6 weeks in advance, noting dietary preferences when booking.
fine_dining.local_tips: Ask for the Scottish cheese trolley and sommelier pairings.

fine_dining.name: The Kitchin
fine_dining.atmosphere: Industrial-chic dining room with open kitchen
fine_dining.booking_tips: Bookings open three months ahead; lunch offers the best availability.
fine_dining.local_tips: Arrive early for a pre-dinner cocktail at the adjacent Kitchin Bar.

fine_dining.name: Number One at The Balmoral
signature_dishes: North Sea cod with shellfish bisque
fine_dining.atmosphere: Warm, understated luxury with tactile fabrics
fine_dining.booking_tips: Request the chef's counter for a view into the kitchen.
fine_dining.local_tips: Pair tasting menus with rare whisky drams curated by the hotel's experts.

fine_dining.name: Fhior
fine_dining.booking_tips: Tasting menus change weekly; note allergies in advance.
fine_dining.local_tips: Opt for the juice pairing for an inventive non-alcoholic experience.

casual_dining.name: Dishoom Edinburgh
casual_dining.atmosphere: Vintage Irani cafe with lively buzz
casual_dining.booking_tips: Join the virtual queue via the app during peak evenings.
casual_dining.local_tips: Order a round of chaijito cocktails during the evening happy hour.

casual_dining.name: Mother India's Cafe
casual_dining.atmosphere: Relaxed townhouse dining with shareable plates
casual_dining.booking_tips: Call ahead for groups; small tables usually available off-peak.
casual_dining.local_tips: Mix and match half portions to sample a wide range of dishes.

casual_dining.name: Makar's Mash Bar
casual_dining.local_tips: Try the whisky flight paired with different mash toppings.

casual_dining.name: The Outsider
casual_dining.atmosphere: Bright loft space overlooking the castle
casual_dining.booking_tips: Ask for a window seat when reserving for castle views.
casual_dining.local_tips: Daily specials highlight produce from East Lothian farms.

street_food.name: The Pitt
street_food.local_tips: Arrive early for the rotating guest traders and live DJs.

street_food.name: Edinburgh Street Food
street_food.local_tips: Scan QR codes to order from multiple vendors at once.

street_food.name: Stockbridge Market
street_food.local_tips: Bring cash for smaller producers and reusable bags for produce.

coffee_shops.name: Brew Lab
coffee_shops.local_tips: Ask baristas about guest roasters rotating weekly.

coffee_shops.name: Fortitude Coffee
coffee_shops.local_tips: Limited seating; grab beans to brew at your accommodation.

coffee_shops.name: Twelve Triangles
coffee_shops.local_tips: Pastries sell out by noon on weekends.

bars.name: Panda & Sons
bars.atmosphere: Hidden barbershop entrance with inventive mixology
bars.local_tips: Book a booth for theatrical table-side cocktails.

bars.name: The Devil's Advocate
bars.atmosphere: Victorian pump house with mezzanine dining
bars.local_tips: Ask staff for a tailored whisky flight based on your palate.

bars.name: Teuchters Landing
bars.atmosphere: Converted ferry waiting room with roaring stove
bars.food_options: Mac 'n' cheese in a mug, seafood pots
bars.local_tips: Visit in summer for drinks on the floating pontoon.

food_tours.name: Eat Walk Edinburgh
food_tours.booking_tips: Tours run rain or shine; wear comfortable shoes for cobblestones.

food_tours.name: Secret Food Tours
food_tours.focus: Grassmarket street food and hidden bakeries

cooking_classes.name: Edinburgh New Town Cookery School
cooking_classes.booking_tips: Book weekend classes a month ahead; vegetarian days available.

cooking_classes.name: The Pantry Workshops
cooking_classes.booking_tips: Workshops held monthly-join newsletter for release dates.

markets.name: Edinburgh Farmers' Market
markets.local_tips: Bring reusable bags and sample smoked salmon from local smokers.

markets.name: Leith Market
markets.local_tips: Combine with a stroll along the Shore for waterfront cafes.

destinations.whyGo: Scotland's largest city offers world-class music venues, Charles Rennie Mackintosh architecture, and energetic nightlife.
Gateway to the Highlands with access to Loch Ness, Culloden Battlefield, and whisky trails.
Granite architecture, North Sea seafood, and ferries to the Northern Isles.
Historic university town famed for its Old Course golf links and medieval cathedral ruins.
Stirling Castle, Wallace Monument, and battlefields that shaped Scotland's history.
Viking heritage, soaring York Minster, and atmospheric medieval walls.
Connect to the UK's capital for West End theatre, national museums, and onward international flights.
Dramatic landscapes, fairy pools, and rugged coastal scenery on Scotland's most famous island.

selfDrive.notes: Best combined with overnight stay; car hire available at EDI.

destinations.whyGo: Seafood capital of Scotland and ferry gateway to the Hebrides.
Titanic heritage, vibrant food scene, and murals exploring Northern Ireland's history.
Literary history, Georgian architecture, and lively pub culture just across the Irish Sea.

ferry.via: Train to Glasgow then bus to Cairnryan

destinations.whyGo: Canals, world-class museums, and effortless cycling culture.
Scandi design, Michelin dining, and waterfront hygge.
Northern lights, geothermal lagoons, and dramatic volcanic landscapes.

activities.name: Cherry Blossom Walk in The Meadows
activities.description: Stroll beneath avenues of cherry trees as locals celebrate the arrival of spring.
activities.seasonal_notes: Peak bloom typically mid-April; picnics and frisbee games common on sunny days.
activities.booking_tips: Arrive early on weekends and bring a blanket for lounging on the grass.

activities.name: Royal Botanic Garden Glasshouses
activities.description: Explore temperate and tropical plant collections sheltered from spring showers.
activities.seasonal_notes: Spring lectures and guided tours highlight rare Scottish alpine species.
activities.booking_tips: Book guided walks online; members enjoy free glasshouse entry.

activities.name: Arthur's Seat Sunrise Hike
activities.description: Climb the volcanic summit for pastel dawn light over the city and coast.
activities.seasonal_notes: Paths can be muddy-wear sturdy footwear and bring windproof layers.
activities.booking_tips: Check sunrise times; guided hikes available via local operators.

activities.name: Edinburgh Science Festival
activities.description: Hands-on experiments, talks, and evening events across museums and venues.
activities.seasonal_notes: Held over the Easter holidays with programming for all ages.
activities.booking_tips: Popular workshops sell out-book tickets two weeks in advance.

activities.name: Portobello Sea Kayaking
activities.description: Paddle along the Firth of Forth with views of Bass Rock and Inchkeith Island.
activities.seasonal_notes: Spring seas remain chilly; wetsuits provided by operators.
activities.booking_tips: Choose calm weather days and check tidal conditions.

activities.name: Edinburgh Festival Fringe
activities.description: Over 3,000 shows spanning comedy, theatre, circus, and spoken word across pop-up venues.
activities.seasonal_notes: August sees streets lined with performers and late-night shows until dawn.
activities.booking_tips: Use the Fringe app for last-minute deals; book top shows months ahead.

activities.name: Royal Edinburgh Military Tattoo
activities.description: Massed pipe bands and fireworks atop the castle esplanade under the night sky.
activities.seasonal_notes: Rain or shine performances-pack waterproofs and a cushion.
activities.booking_tips: Tickets release in December and sell quickly-consider midweek shows for availability.

activities.name: Leith Waterfront Dining
activities.description: Enjoy alfresco seafood and cocktails along the Shore as sunsets linger.
activities.seasonal_notes: Outdoor terraces open May-September; evenings can be breezy.
activities.booking_tips: Reserve patio tables; bring a light layer for cooler nights.

activities.name: Portobello Beach Day
activities.description: Swim, paddleboard, or simply unwind on Edinburgh's sandy beach.
activities.seasonal_notes: Water remains cool-wetsuits recommended for longer swims.
activities.booking_tips: Arrive early on warm weekends; rent boards from beachfront kiosks.

activities.name: Roof Terrace Cinema
activities.description: Catch films under the stars atop city rooftops with deckchairs and blankets.
activities.seasonal_notes: Pop-up programmes run June-August with classic and cult screenings.
activities.booking_tips: Bring layers; some venues allow BYO snacks.

activities.name: Calton Hill Sunset
activities.description: Watch the city glow beneath autumn skies framed by neo-classical monuments.
activities.seasonal_notes: Golden hour arrives earlier; pack a hot drink for breezy evenings.
activities.booking_tips: Head up 30 minutes before sunset to secure a spot.

activities.name: Bonfire Night Celebrations
activities.description: Fireworks and torchlight displays mark Guy Fawkes Night on 5 November.
activities.seasonal_notes: Major displays on Calton Hill and Meadowbank Stadium.
activities.booking_tips: Some events require pre-registration-check council listings.

activities.name: Whisky Tasting in the Old Town
activities.description: Sample single malts and learn about regional styles at atmospheric bars.
activities.seasonal_notes: Autumn releases feature limited-edition bottlings.
activities.booking_tips: Book guided tastings at The Scotch Whisky Experience or The Devil's Advocate.

activities.name: Rosslyn Chapel Day Trip
activities.description: Explore ornate carvings and legend-filled chapels amid woodland foliage.
activities.seasonal_notes: Combine with walks through Roslin Glen's autumn colors.
activities.booking_tips: Pre-book timed entry slots during weekends.

activities.name: Samhuinn Fire Festival
activities.description: Modern interpretation of Celtic New Year with fire choreography on the Royal Mile.
activities.seasonal_notes: Held on 31 October with elaborate costumes and drums.
activities.booking_tips: Tickets released in early autumn; dress warmly for night-time chill.

activities.name: Edinburgh Christmas Market
activities.description: Festive stalls, rides, and mulled wine fill Princes Street Gardens.
activities.seasonal_notes: Runs mid-November to early January with ice skating and Ferris wheel.
activities.booking_tips: Book weekend ice rink slots online; visit weekday evenings for fewer crowds.

activities.name: Hogmanay Street Party
activities.description: World-famous New Year's celebration with concerts, countdown, and fireworks.
activities.seasonal_notes: Tickets include street access; expect temperature near freezing.
activities.booking_tips: Buy tickets when released in summer; arrange accommodation far in advance.

activities.name: Burns Night Supper
activities.description: Celebrate 25 January with poetry, haggis, and ceilidh dancing.
activities.seasonal_notes: Venues across the city host formal or casual suppers.
activities.booking_tips: Reserve mid-December; vegetarian haggis available on request.

activities.name: National Museum of Scotland
activities.description: Warm up indoors exploring natural history and Scottish innovation galleries.
activities.seasonal_notes: Winter programming includes family workshops and late openings.
activities.booking_tips: Arrive near opening to enjoy quieter galleries.

activities.name: Ross Bandstand Ice Rink
activities.description: Seasonal outdoor rink with castle backdrop and festive lighting.
activities.seasonal_notes: Operates November-January; sessions last 45 minutes.
activities.booking_tips: Book online to secure skate hire; gloves recommended.

ranges.notes: New Year's celebrations linger with the Loony Dook swim in South Queensferry; many attractions open late.
Quiet galleries, crisp winter walks, and whisky tastings make early January peaceful and good value.

Edinburgh lights festival and quiet museums make early February atmospheric.
Half-term brings family-friendly events at Dynamic Earth and the zoo.
Longer days and snowdrop festivals in nearby gardens signal spring.
Edinburgh Science Festival previews begin; gardens show first blooms.
Murrayfield match weekends fill hotels and pubs.
Shoulder season sweet spot with longer evenings and moderate prices.
Easter markets and cherry blossom in full bloom across The Meadows.
Interactive exhibits excite families and curious travelers across the city.
Long daylight hours and mild temps encourage hill walks and day trips.
Blue skies, gorse in bloom on Arthur's Seat, and Beltane Fire Festival finale.
considerations: Bring warm layers for night events

ranges.notes: Shoulder season for golf at St Andrews and distillery day trips.
Warmer evenings perfect for rooftop bars and sunset walks along the Water of Leith.
Long daylight and mild weather perfect for Highlands day trips.
